comments.commentBody: It becomes more and more obvious that News Corporation is not, in fact, a news service, but is rather an espionage organization with a news service as its cover. Perhaps it should be treated as such, with all the powers of the Patriot Act set in motion against it.

Why would anyone doubt that Fox News has been doing the same snooping, or worse, in the United States?  The number of Republican politicians in direct employment to Fox News suggest that Fox is employing them as a wall of defense.  Fox is basically stating that Republicans can be counted upon to protect Fox News , because Fox News pays them, and if Fox News goes down the Republicans will no longer get their big fat payoffs.

With the death of the whistle blower, this is starting to read like The Godfather.  Today anything can look like natural causes.  And the Scotland Yard excuses reeks of corruption.  Are we really to believe none of this is happening here with so many media outlets being owned by Murdoch?  I think all no-bid contracts the city has with Murdoch owned companies should be tabled.  The fact they are not just goes to show how much political and financial pull the Murdochs have on this city and state.

The cause of Sean Hoare's death has been determined "not suspicious", but I bet it is considered rather "convenient" around the Murdoch holdings as well as inside Scotland Yard.

The culture of lawlessness at News Corp. is directed from the top of the organization - remember the stories told by the news writers and reporters who were either fired or left The Post after Murdoch bought it? - those who refused to go along with the program were cut out, ostracized, even physically threatened, and who knows whether Mr Hoare found out just how far these slugs were willing to go to hide their slime trail.

Not "suspicious" but rather "convenient".

Good news, I hope they end the "Essential" Air Service Program completely. As noted, many of these markets receive generous subsidies even though they are driving distance from major airports. The example in the article is great and reminds me of the story last year about the subsidies Macon, Georgia receives through this program that come out to $400 per round trip passenger. Macon is an easy hour and a half drive from the largest airport in the world (ATL), sorry but if you choose to live in an isolated area you should be able to stomach the fact that you have to drive an hour and a half to a major international airport (or eat the extra costs you should be paying in the first place for the convenience of flying out of a tiny market). It's time for very good federal government programs to get a haircut and its time for the other programs to end completely.

This is what happens when, since the Reagan administration in the 80's, we seriously cut research and development in commercial aviation, as well as other high speed transportation technologies.

Republican cuts in infrastructure investment have also taken their toll. We can't even build an extra train tunnel from NY to NJ without some myopic republican governor cancelling the entire deal.

If we had been making the proper investments in public transportation during the last few decades, we wouldn't be seeing symptoms like this.

We ought to have a network of super high speed (at least 500-1000 mph or faster) trains running between major and minor cities throughout the nation as well as good commuter rail lines in as many regions as possible. Not only would it save money for the country but it would seriously increase economic activity of all kinds, wherever it exists.

Eisenhower, the last liberal republican, knew and understood this idea, when he signed into law Senator Al Gore Sr's Federal highway act, giving us a national highway system that is still the envy of the world. It's time to do something for the country again, politicians. Make the investment, so we can all enjoy the rewards.
Make your decision: Farm Bill subsidies or air service via Delta.

We have had the worst of it here in the middle of Georgia.  We lost our regional jets, then the replacement twin turboprops went.  We then got EAS service using single engine turboprop unpressurized Cessna Caravans.  We had gone from eight depatures per day to two.  We ended up with the largest EAS per passenger subsidy in the continental USA.  Even then the load factors went down and the service is ending.  But throughout the past 20 years of ever lowering air service we have been fortunate to have a private van shuttle to Atlanta International Airport ATL. Vans run about 1 per hour, 24 hours per day, 7 days a week.  I hope the communities that loose air service have van/bus services rise up to take up the task.  Its not the most comfortable way to travel, but it beats having nothing.  Our main airport stays open to handle private aircraft, charter flights, airliner repairs, flight training, and cargo flights.  So we do get some economic benefit.

For many years, airlines received subsidies to sustain them. I recall bags of mail strapped into passenger seats during the 50s.

Whether this is good now is an open question, perhaps, but for many of us subsidies provide air service to areas we could not otherwise visit without an integrated ground support system.

The vastness of the American West makes air travel to small cities desirable. It is a long way from Portland, Oregon to Pendleton, Oregon. For some other states, you folks elect representatives and senators who do not favor government spending except for farms and thinks like rural airports. You elected the attitude that destroys your air service.

Delta doesn't have the can-do attitude that we are told is characteristic of American business.  Instead of coming up with an innovative solution, with the right kind of plane, Delta seems to be no-can-do, wanting guaranteed profits dumped in their lap by the government.

It's hard to feel sympathy for Muscle Shoals -- Huntsville is only 69 miles away, an easy commute, plus the weather will cooperate.  However, it's hard to feel sympathy for the journalist writing this article -- Pierre is somewhere between 170 and 190 miles from Rapid City (Google maps anyone?), not 140 miles as indicated. And it is the capital, which should count for somthing.

Prof. Glaeser’s fascinating research shows, “There is a near perfect correlation between urbanization and prosperity across nations.” Countries with more cities and urban areas are almost uniformly better endowed in most fundamental areas of well-being, including everything from income to cultural stimulation. Cities and their critical role in facilitating effective communication are all-the-more-important as globalization increases contact across diverse cultures and backgrounds. By enabling face-to-face interactions, world cities are vital “tools for reducing the complex-communication curse” and engendering effective cross-cultural collaboration and understanding. Source: Global Sherpa, http://www.globalsherpa.org/city-development-economic-ed-glaeser.

When I was a kid we played on concrete, dangling from metal monkey bars with rust and peeling lead-based paint on them. I loved climbing up a mountain of old rotting tires strung together on a sloping hill. A favorite at the park was a cargo net made out of chain link that you get about 15 feet up on and just dangle there over the concrete. A couple of parks has old fire engines in them and we LOVED those fire engines. You could climb all over their rusted carcasses and have a blast amongst the exposed bolts, loose bits of metal and oh! those ladders.

And we lived.

There was a sense of risk...and the risk was real. We skinned our knees and we cried, and it made us realize that a little blood and a little pain wasn't going to kill us. We were competitive...and there were winners AND losers. Not everyone got trophies just for "trying their best". Sometimes our best wasn't good enough and fun and the challenge of competing had to be enough of a reward.

Today I teach high school. I wish that more of my students had grown up on playgrounds that were a little less safe and a little more challenging. Maybe they wouldn't be so afraid to do anything resembling hard work, maybe they would realize that failure is part of learning, and maybe they would realize that competition can bring out the best in people...even if it means risking losing and being disappointed.

Of course...when I was a kid and someone fell off of the monkey bars and broke their arm...which happened...they didn't sue the city. We just signed their cast and life went on...and the next time they were on the monkey bars they were more focused and more careful. Amazing how that works. We call it "learning".

Cap frivolous lawsuits and bogus causes of action, and, especially, sanction the lawyers, not so much the plaintiffs, who bring bogus cases into court.  Cap legal fees.  Stop making the legal class your ruling class (watch the big joke of a Congress right now -- how many are lawyers?).

In a word, yes.

We need to initiate a class action suit against manufacturers of playground equipment whose product-related child injuries fall below a threshold rate - by yesterday.

Further, we need big yellow signs - prominently displayed - warning when equipment is too safe. Quadrilingual - and with sharp metal edges.

My daughter is two and a half and she is already starting to get bored with the playground equipment that is allegedly for 5-12 year old kids.

Make the playgrounds boring if you must, but kids will still want excitement... I guess the next step for her is to play in traffic and leave the playground equipment for the 3 and under set?
Considering the number of parents who believe the Parks Department should be accountable for everything from sprinkler water potability to the heat of the sun, I expect calls for a retraction.

Just yesterday my elementary-school-age children were disappointed to see that the great merry-go-around at the River Run Playground in Riverside Park (at W 83rd) has been removed.
We love raising them in NYC but having to be on the lookout for park personnel when your young child climbs a strong tree in Central Park is ridiculous. Tree climbing is in fact forbidden in all of Central Park. We would never let the kids harm any trees and have volunteered as a family for the Central Park Conservancy.

Someone has suggested that the AG should launch an enquiry into this Murdoch bloke and, of course, his media dealings in the United States. Fox News: it is now time to get down on your knees, along with those who spew negativity all about.
Not, all the Kings horses and not all the Kings men, could not put Humpty back together again.

Why is the PM of Britain meeting with the lady head of the Murdoch empire and other of its top execs twice a month since taking office, and hiring an ex top editor as his communications chief? Now, the chief rat if found dead, yet not "suspicious"?  The whole thing stinks like rotten roquefort...

John Burns' excellent article accurately explains the stage on which this telephone hacking scandal is being played. It should be noted that all British political parties courted favor with Mr. Murdoch's  newspapers.  Mr. Milliband's sanctimonious criticism of David Cameron rings hollow in light of his labour party's history.  He sees an opening to attack the Prime Minister during his foreign trip. It would be prudent to wait for the results of a thorough investigation of this matter before rendering judgment on those found guilty. This scandal has aroused a vigilante mentality unworthy of civilized people. These crimes were committed against innocent people.  The guilty must be accountable to the judicial system. But I am reminded that for some of the most vocal critics Shakespeare's "Methinks thou dost protest too much" applies.
They operated just like our lobbysts do, trying to change the perspective of lawmakers with food for thought, cold hard cash.

Murdoch will surely run the gauntlet of hate outside the Commons Committee today. But can the scarecrows inside Committee make this artful fox confess his skullduggery? Murdoch has an additional and far more dangerous weapon in his armory – a withering look. Some of the MPs who were for so long his cheerleaders would shy away from asking him tough questions. At the end of the day, we will get the right answers but not the right questions. Even as Murdoch is flailing and the carrion crows are gathering overhead, a mere look from him at the craven MPs would still send a cold shiver down their spine. Ever the actors, the MPs can be trusted to waffle and flannel at critical moments.
I think that with the death of Osama bin Laden, News Corp has surpassed al Qaeda as a danger to Western democratic institutions.  Time to boycott the whole stinking thing.
